awd_abstract_narration:
Quantum systems can exist simultaneously in different physical states.  This fundamental property of nature, known as quantum coherence, or superposition,  is widely believed to represent an essential ingredient in a variety of fields ranging from quantum information processing and quantum metrology to quantum biology. This project aims to develop a powerful and general scientific framework to assess and control the coherence generating power of quantum processes, both natural and artificial.  This is important because the ability to efficiently generate quantum coherence lies at the very heart of all quantum technologies, and underpins their potential for huge societal impact based on unprecedented computational and communication power.  This project thus aims to promote the progress of fundamental science, and it will help to foster the development of potentially disruptive quantum technological applications.

This team will introduce mathematical measures to quantify the coherence generating power of various quantum mechanical operations associated with physical processes.  The mathematical approach is based on probabilistic tools and completely positive maps.  Rigorous results that are amenable to direct experimental tests will be derived.  This approach introduces a formulation in terms of elegant geometrical structures, both global and local. This team will also extend this conceptual and mathematical framework in several directions including studies of open quantum systems and quantum algorithms.  This team will also explore the connection of quantum coherence with some fundamental and fascinating problems in modern condensed matter physics e.g., many-body localization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum Coherence is the ability, displayed by quantum-mechanical systems, to exist is a well-defined superposition of different, distinguishable physical configurations e.g., being in two places at the same time. This astounding fact represents one of the key non-classical features of quantum mechanics which, in turn, may provide an important resource for the efficient and fast solution of some important computational and information-processing tasks. 

Quantum Coherence, in short, in one of the pillars at the basis of any novel quantum technology: how do we produce and maintain it? 

The primary Goal of this Project was to 1) design conceptual and mathematical tools to analyze the coherence generating capabilities of general quantum systems, isolated as well as interacting with their environment. As a secondary goal 2) we applied our novel tools to a variety of concrete physical models e.g., spin chains, to assess their effectiveness.  

Both Goals have been fully achieved by the introduction of measures of coherence generating power (CGP) for unitary and general quantum channels. As a by-product we were also able to connect, in a quantitative and rigorous fashion, CGP with other fascinating phenomena like quantum chaos and many-body localization in disordered and interacting multi-qubit systems.

A third, originally unplanned, Goal achieved during the Lifetime of this Project was 3) the discovery of a deep and precise connection between coherence generating power and other two famous quantum properties: scrambling and quantum entanglement at the operator space level. Scrambling refers to the ability of some ``chaotic" quantum systems to quickly  spread (i.e., ``scramble") information, which was at the start encoded locally e.g., in one qubit, across a full network of coupled quantum units. Operator entanglement is an important technical notion which quantifies the degree of complexity of a quantum dynamics.

We found that CGP (see above) is just a special member of a vast family of quantitative measures of "algebra scrambling" defined by specific set of measurements capabilities. Another example being the (Averaged) Out of Time Order Correlation (OTOC) function used to study quantum scrambling in chaotic systems. This OTOC was shown to coincide with operator entanglement and its long-time behavior contains a wealth of information about the full system of energy states, and has the power of distinguishing different classes of quantum-mechanical systems e.g., integrable vs chaotic.  

Our findings provide a powerful conceptual and mathematically elegant framework to describe and analyze apparently different quantum phenomena e.g., CGP & OTOC, from a single, unified, vantage point.

The team consisted of the PI and, overall, of four graduate students. The latter helped the PI in developing the mathematical  theory, performing computer-aided analysis of data and in writing the scientific  publications in which our results have been published. The project provided the students with an invaluable personal experience,great  professional training and intellectual growth. This included participating to conferences and workshops abroad and disseminating the project outcomes by talks. Two of the students are now graduated and  are moving forward with  their careers in internationally prestigious scientific institutions.
